sources.why: Miami-Dade County official page on liquid waste transporters permits - authoritative source for permit requirements
Florida Department of Health regulations for septic contractors and pumping services
Miami-Dade County septic system standards including drainfield elevation requirements for high water table
Florida DEP FAQ on septic contracting, licensing, and service requirements

linkable_points: Miami-Dade County requires all liquid waste transporters to hold a valid permit (Ordinance 22-83, effective January 2023)
Florida septic contractors must be registered with the Department of Health and renew annually
Miami-Dade drainfield requirements: bottom must be at least 36 inches above wet season high water table
Operating permits for advanced treatment systems in Miami-Dade are valid for 5 years and require renewal
Routine septic pumping typically takes 1-3 hours depending on tank size and access
Most residential septic systems in Miami need pumping every 3-5 years, but high usage or small tanks may require annual service
Miami's high water table and heavy rainfall can accelerate sludge buildup, requiring more frequent pumping
Hurricane season (June-November) often causes increased septic issues due to flooding and system saturation

cost_methodology: Ranges commonly reported by Miami-Dade licensed contractors. Factors include tank size, access difficulty, waste disposal fees, and emergency surcharges.
local_factors: High water table requires systems to be 36+ inches above seasonal high water
Heavy rainfall and flooding during hurricane season can overwhelm systems
Saltwater intrusion in coastal areas (Brickell, Key Biscayne) can damage systems
Coral rock and limestone soil affect drainage and system design
